questions.text: Your co-intern requests the unit chief leave for the weekend, which is denied by the chief. However, on Saturday morning, he complains of severe pain in the abdomen but examination and investigations could not lead to a diagnosis. Which of the following should be considered?
questions.solution:
The scenario described is suggestive of malingering as the patient falsely complained of abdominal pain to avail leave from work.

Malingering is the intentional falsification of physical or psychological symptoms to achieve some practical gain such as financial compensation, avoidance of criminal responsibility or military service, or leave from work. Usually, there is an obvious discrepancy between the complaints and objective findings. The individual is uncooperative during the evaluation and does not comply with the treatment plan proposed. It can be associated with an antisocial personality disorder. In some circumstances, such as while held captive during a war, it can be an adaptive behavior.

Other options:

Option B: Factitious disorder /Munchausen syndrome is the intentional production of physical symptoms to get medical attention. There is no intention to obtain a practical gain.

Option C: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the presence of general and non-delu­sional preoccupation with developing a serious disease for ≥6 months. It is based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. These preoccupied thoughts cause significant distress and impairment in one's life.

Option D: Dissociative fugue refers to sudden travel away from home associated with partial or complete memory loss about one's identity.

questions.text: A young man brings his wife to the psychiatrist, saying she has had spells of uncontrollable overeating followed by self-induced vomiting at least 1-2 times every week for the past four months. There is no history of restriction of food intake, and her body mass index is found to be 19 kg/m2.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting, with weight within the normal range, is bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is marked by episodes of binge eating in individuals with a morbid fear of being fat. This is followed by compensatory behaviours such as self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, and the use of enemas. This is done to prevent weight gain. This pattern is seen at least once a week for ≥3 months. It is commonly seen in women. The weight is usually within the normal range. In some cases, the patients are obese or underweight. Sexual activity remains unaffected, unlike anorexia nervosa patients, who are usually not interested in sex.

It can be treated with cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy. CBT involves disrupting the cycle of repeated binge eating-purging and changing the patient's beliefs about food, body weight, and body image. Important drugs used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa are fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Anorexia nervosa is diagnosed by the presence of restriction of food intake that leads to significantly low body weight. Intense fear of gaining weight or persistent behaviour that interferes with weight gain is seen.

Option C: Avoidant food intake disorder is commonly seen in infancy or early childhood. It is characterized by a lack of interest in eating food. This is based on the sensory features of food or the perceived consequences of eating. The patients have significant nutritional deficiencies.

Option D: Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating without the recurrent use of compensatory behaviours.

questions.text: A patient admitted to the ICU for severe pneumonia 5 days ago suddenly developed difficulty in recognizing his relatives or the doctor and has started muttering that he is trapped in jail. On evaluation, he is in an altered sensorium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ICU psychosis (delirium).

The following features are consistent with the diagnosis of delirium:

  • Acute onset of symptoms
  • Disorientation to place (jail instead of the hospital)
  • Disorientation to person (failure to recognize relatives and the doctor)
  • Altered sensorium

Brief psychotic disorder (BPD) according to DSM-5 is the sudden onset of psychotic behaviour that lasts less than 1 month followed by complete remission with possible future relapses. This is termed acute and transient psychotic disorder as per ICD-11, and the duration of the episode should not exceed 3 months.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of depression presents with suicidal ideation. On further questioning, he reveals that he has had a previous suicide attempt and no family support.  Which of the following is not an indication for hospitalization?

choices.text: Absence of a strong social support system

questions.solution:
The ability to discuss safety planning is not an indication for hospitalization in this patient.

Indications for hospitalization for suicide prevention include the following: 

  • Suicidal plan of action
  • Inability to discuss safety planning
  • Absence of a strong social support system
  • History of impulsive behavior
  • Psychotic patient 
  • Precautions were taken to evade discovery
  • Severe agitation, poor judgment, and refusal to accept help

A suicide attempt is a psychiatric emergency. While suicide is hard to predict, the patient may unintentionally provide clues to the same. Some high-risk factors for suicide are male sex, age above 45, unemployment, multiple attempts at suicide, and social isolation. Most people who have committed or attempted suicide have an underlying mental disorder, of which depression and schizophrenia are the most common.

During hospitalization, objects that can be used for self-harm should be removed. Anti-depressants or antipsychotics are used depending on the underlying condition. Individual therapy, group therapy, and family therapy are other useful measures.

Suicide attempts and thoughts are more common in women, but the rate of committing suicide is more in men. Suicide rates increase with age and are rare before puberty.

questions.text: Which of the following is false?

choices.text: A  person suffering from a somatic delusion has testamentary capacity
A mentally ill person can give evidence during lucid interval
A mentally ill person is not criminally responsible during lucid interval
A person suffering from delusions of grandiosity cannot make a will

questions.solution:
A mentally ill person is indeed criminally responsible during the lucid interval.

Lucid interval: The period of sanity or consciousness between two periods of insanity or unconsciousness. Seen in states like mania, melancholia, extradural hemorrhage.

During this period, a mentally ill person:

  • Can give evidence.
  • Is criminally responsible.
  • Has testamentary capacity.

Testamentary capacity is the mental ability of a person to make a will. A person of a sound disposing mind at the time of making the will (not necessarily always) can make a will. A person suffering from an insane delusion can make a will if the delusion is not related in any way by the disposal of property or the persons affected. For example:

  • Delusion of grandeur: cannot make a will, as they believe they possess more than they actually do.
  • Delusion of persecution: might not be allowed to make a will, because it will affect who they distribute their property to.
  • Somatic delusions: can make a will. Only has delusions of physical symptoms, who they distribute their property to is not affected.

questions.text: During Ross's marriage to Emily, when the wedding officiant asked him to repeat “I Ross, take thee, Emily, as my lawfully wedded wife”, Ross says Rachel's name instead. Ross and Rachel have dated on multiple occasions in the past. This unconscious act of revealing his feelings can be best described by which of the following terms?
questions.solution:
When a person reveals his feelings unconsciously by a slip of tongue, it is known as parapraxis. Freud ascribed parapraxis to unconscious motives.

Option B: Transference - A situation where the feelings, desires, and expectations of one person are redirected and applied to another person. Most commonly, transference occurs in a therapeutic setting, where a person in therapy unconsciously develop feelings towards the therapist.

Option C: Repression - is a key concept of psychoanalysis, where it is understood as a defense mechanism. It ensures that what is unacceptable to the conscious mind - and would, if recalled arouse anxiety - is prevented from entering into it.

Option D: Displacement - Feelings that are connected with one person are displaced onto another person. E.g., a man who has had a bad day at the office, comes home and yells at his wife and children, is displacing his anger from the workplace onto his family.

Catharsis: The expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed emotions by the patient which provides a sense of relief. It is also known as ventilation. In catharsis, the patient reveals information voluntarily and consciously whereas, in parapraxis, patient details are revealed unconsciously, by slip of tongue.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is conducting the Folstein test as a part of the psychiatric evaluation of a patient. Which of the following is being evaluated?
questions.solution:
The Folstein test also known as the mini-mental state examination (MMSE) is used to test cognitive functioning.

MMSE is a 30-point questionnaire from categories including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language which tallies up to a score of 30. It is easy to administer and takes less than ten minutes for completion. A score of less than 24 points to cognitive impairment.

It can be used to screen for and assess dementia. Some other screening tools are the Montreal cognitive assessment (MOCA), the tablet-based cognitive assessment tool, and cognistat.

questions.text:
Abuse of which of the following drugs will lead to the finding as shown in the image below?
  1. Heroin
  2. Cocaine
  3. Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD)
  4. Mescaline
  5. Cannabis
questions.solution:
The given image shows circular depressed skin popping scars in this patient. Among the given options, opioids like heroin and cocaine abuse ( 1 and 2) can lead to this.

Skin popping is a method of injecting illicit drugs into the skin. Illicit drugs like heroin, cocaine, and barbiturates are injected by this method. It has slower absorption, decreased risk of overdose, and easier administration when compared to intravenous drug use. Skin popping scars point to possible drug use.

Opioids can be taken orally, snorted, or injected intravenously. It results in a euphoric high, especially with the intravenous route. The associated features are heaviness of the extremities, dry mouth, itchy face, and facial flushing. It can result in constipation, pupillary constriction, and changes in blood pressure. The clinical triad of coma, pinpoint pupils, and respiratory depression points are suggestive of opioid overdose. Respiratory depression can even lead to death.

Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), mescaline (hallucinogen), and cannabis are not usually taken through injections, but commonly by oral route or through smoking.

Head-to-toe examination in cases of substance abuse becomes important to look for such skin findings. Long-term use of cocaine can result in cocaine nose, with perforation of the nasal septum, as seen in the image below.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was referred to you for further evaluation for dementia. After a detailed clinical and laboratory examination, you diagnose this patient to be suffering from subcortical dementia. Subcortical dementia can occur in all of the following conditions, except _____.
questions.solution:
Subcortical dementia can be seen in all the above conditions except Alzheimer's disease, which is an example of cortical dementia.

Dementia or major neurocognitive disorder is a progressive and irreversible intellectual impairment that increases with age. It is seen more commonly in women. It is classified into cortical and subcortical dementia based on the site of the cerebral lesion.

Examples of cortical dementia are Alzheimer's disease, Pick's disease, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Common causes of subcortical dementia include Parkinson's disease, vascular dementia, Huntington's disease, Wilson's disease, and normal pressure hydrocephalus.

questions.text:
A young mother is experiencing tearfulness and mood swings 5 days after her baby was born. She is suspected to have postpartum blues. All are true regarding this condition except?

DSM-5: Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition

choices.text: Occurs due to hormonal changes after childbirth
Evaluate for postpartum depression if symptoms last >2 weeks
Main treatment is support and education
Subtype of bipolar disorder in DSM-5

questions.solution:
Postpartum blues is not a subtype of bipolar disorder in DSM-5 (Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition). 

Postpartum blues is a common condition seen in mothers during the puerperal period. It is characterized by transient mood disturbances like a labile mood, sadness, and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels and the stress of childbirth. The anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood is also a contributory factor. Education and support form the mainstay of management. However, symptoms lasting longer than 2 weeks should be evaluated for postpartum depression.

Postpartum depression is marked by a depressed mood, excessive anxiety, insomnia, and weight changes usually within the 4-6 weeks of delivery. There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby, which is not present in postpartum blues. It is a subtype of major depressive disorder in DSM-5.

Postpartum psychosis or puerperal psychosis is a psychotic disorder that may occur in women after delivery. It is listed as a subtype of bipolar disorder in DSM-5. The condition is characterized by depression, delusions, and thoughts of harming either herself or her infant. Suicidal ideation or infanticidal thoughts should be carefully monitored. The mean time of onset is usually within the first 2-3 weeks following delivery. Subsequent pregnancies are associ­ated with an increased risk of a second episode.

questions.text: A male patient came to your clinic with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and tiredness throughout the day. He says that he gets sudden attacks of sleep while he talks to his clients at the office. Which of the following is unlikely to be found associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of narcolepsy. Somniloquy is unlikely to be found associated with this condition.

Somniloquy is the unconscious speech during sleep. It may accompany other sleep disorders like night terror and sleepwalking.

Narcolepsy is marked by sleep attacks leading to 10-20 minutes of sleep. After this, the patient feels refreshed but remains tired throughout the rest of the day. It can happen at inappropriate times such as while working, eating, talking, or driving. The onset is usually between the ages of 10-20 years, after which it persists for life.

Cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness), hypnopompic (hallucinations upon awakening), or hypnagogic (hallucinations at the onset of sleep) hallucinations are associated features. Sleep paralysis may also be seen, in which the patient upon awakening will be unable to move his muscles.

A polysomnogram and multiple sleep latency tests are done to diagnose the condition. Modafinil, methylphenidate, and venlafaxine are the drugs used in the management.

questions.text: You notice a patient lying in the hospital compound with his attendant, to be seen by a psychiatrist. He does not react when you lend him a hand to make him stand. He doesn't move or respond to any other instruction given by the attendant. This behavior can be best described as:
questions.solution:
The behavior of not responding to instructions and external stimuli is known as negativism.

Negativism is a feature seen in catatonia. Verbal or nonverbal opposition to suggestions or advice is exhibited. There is resistance to efforts to be moved and the patient might even do the opposite of what is asked.

Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. It is a new diagnostic category in the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5). A diagnosis of catatonia is not made if there is a primary mental disorder such as schizophrenia or psychotic depression, or if present during the course of delirium. 

Abnormal behaviors include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing. Wavy flexibility is marked by uniform resistance offered to passive positioning. Catalepsy is a passively inducted posture that is maintained against gravity by the patient. 

Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. It can also be seen in neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

The primary treatment for catatonia includes identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed. Benzodiazepines are effective in reducing the symptoms of catatonia temporarily. Electroconvulsive therapy should be started for catatonia that is not responding to benzodiazepines and in severe cases with life-threatening conditions such as refusal to eat. 

Other options:

Option A: Mannerisms are normal movements that look odd and are involuntary. 

Option B: Stereotypy is purposeless repetitive speech or movements.

Option D: Echopraxia is characterized by mimicking an observed movement.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man has been diagnosed with advanced-stage testicular cancer with multiple metastatic sites. The oncologist informs him that his chances of survival are very poor. Which of the following is the right sequence of the stages that this patient will experience according to Elisabeth Kubler-Ross?
  1. Bargaining
  2. Acceptance
  3. Depression
  4. Anger
  5. Denial
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the stages that this patient will experience according to Elisabeth Kubler-Ross is 5, 4, 1, 3, and 2.

A patient diagnosed with a terminal disease responds to impending death by the five stages proposed by Kubler-Ross which are in the order as follows :

  • Shock and Denial
  • Anger
  • Bargaining
  • Depression
  • Acceptance

Stage 1 is the stage of shock and denial. The individual initially reacts with shock when told that they are dying and may refuse to believe the diagnosis. A few may never pass this stage and may change doctors until they find one who supports their position.

Stage 2  is the stage of anger. The person becomes frustrated, irritable, and angry. At this stage, they commonly ask the question "Why me?". They may blame themselves or might displace their anger onto the hospital staff members and the doctor, whom they blame for the illness. Patients in the stage of anger are the ones difficult to treat.

Stage 3 is also known as the stage of bargaining. The patient may attempt to negotiate with physicians, friends, or even God in return for curing him or her. Treating such a patient involves reassurance that they will be looked after to the best of the doctor's abilities. 

Stage 4 is depression. In this stage, patients exhibit clinical signs of depression. These include withdrawal, psychomotor retardation, sleep disturbances, and hopelessness. These symptoms may be due to the effects of the illness on their lives or due to the anticipation of the eventual loss of life. This may require antidepressants or electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).

Stage 5 is the stage of acceptance. The patient eventually realizes that death is inevitable, and they accept the universality of the experience. The feelings of the patient can range from a neutral state to euphoria.

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc).

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to you with sleep deprivation, elation, and talkativeness for the last 4 days, but his social and occupational functioning is intact. He also complains of irritability and distractibility and gives a history of three episodes of major depression in the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features of decreased sleep, irritability, distractibility, elation, and talkativeness for 4 days with intact social and occupational functioning suggest an episode of hypomania. Since the patient has had episodes of major depression in the past, the diagnosis is bipolar disorder II.

Types of Bipolar disorder:

  • Bipolar I: Episodes of mania with or without episodes of major depressive disorder. At least one-lifetime episode of mania is required for diagnosis. 
  • Bipolar II: Episodes of hypomania with episodes of major depressive disorder. Major depressive episodes lasting at least 2 weeks and hypomanic episodes lasting for at least 4 days are required for diagnosis. A negative history of a manic episodes is needed for making a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder.

Mania presents with features similar to hypomania but for a duration of at least one week. There is a marked impairment in social and occupational functioning.

The age of onset for bipolar type I disorder ranges from, children of ages 5-6 years to adults aged 50 or above. The mean age of onset is 30 years. The lifetime prevalence of bipolar type 1 disorder is 0 to 2.4%, whereas bipolar type 2 disorder is 0.3-4.8%. Bipolar type 1 disorder is seen with an equal prevalence among men and women. Suicide attempt is seen in approximately 15% of patients affected by bipolar disorder. 

Lithium is used in the pharmacological management of bipolar disorder. Along with it, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines are also used.

Other options:

Option B: Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than two years in adults (1 year in children and adolescents). It is not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression and has an insidious onset. The low mood persists for most of the day.

Option C: Euphoria is an emotional condition marked by intense feelings of well-being, elation, happiness, and joy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 3 episodes of mania and 2 episodes of depression within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has a combination of 4 or more alternating episodes of depression and mania/hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: A newly married couple has come for counseling as the male partner has had difficulty maintaining an erection until the completion of sexual activity for the past 8 months. He does not have any known ailment. Which phase of the normal sexual cycle does this disorder belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of erectile dysfunction, which is a disorder of the arousal phase (excitement phase) of the normal sexual cycle.

Erectile dysfunction is marked by difficulty in achieving or maintaining an erection. A considerable decrease in penile rigidity during erection is also associated. All or one of these symptoms must be present during intercourse for at least six months for a diagnosis. It causes significant distress to the individual.

Patients who have had lifelong erectile disorder have never been able to obtain an erection sufficient for insertion. Acquired male erectile disorder is marked by successful penetration at some point in his sexual life but is now unable to do so. Erectile dysfunction experienced in particular circumstances is termed situational male erectile disorder.

Other options:

Option A: The desire phase consists of sexual fantasies and the desire to have sex. This phase is affected in people with frigidity(lack of sexual desire).

Option B: The orgasmic phase lasts for 3-15 seconds. It is marked by ejaculation. This phase is affected in people with premature ejaculation.

Option D: The resolution phase lasts for 10-15 minutes. If no orgasm is achieved, it can last for 1/2 -1 day. It is marked by full detumescence in 5-30 minutes. Detumescence is the release of vascular activity and muscle tone after orgasm.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on EEG finding highlighted in red.
questions.solution:
The marked area in the given EEG shows sawtooth waves that are characteristic of REM sleep.

Sleep is comprised of two distinct physiological states, non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and REM sleep. Stages I to IV make up the NREM sleep with marked lower physiological functions than during wakefulness. Dreams which occur during this state are usually lucid and purposeful.

REM sleep is characterized by a high level of brain activity. The physiological activity is similar to that during wakefulness. In REM sleep,

  • Pulse, respiration, and blood pressure are increased.
  • Brain oxygen use increases during REM sleep.
  • Thermoregulation is altered - Poikilothermia prevails during REM sleep.
  • There is loss of muscle tone - body movements are absent during REM sleep.
  • There is partial or full penile erection - This is used to evaluate the cause for impotence.
  • Dreams are abstract and surreal.

In normal adults, a REM episode has a latency of about 90 minutes during which the sleep is in the NREM stage. This latency is shortened in narcolepsy and depressive disorders.

questions.text: A 40-year-old psychiatric patient is admitted for electroconvulsive therapy. He is likely to be suffering from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The patient is likely to be suffering from major depression with psychosis, which is an indication for electroconvulsive therapy.

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) involves inducing a bilateral generalized seizure in an anesthetized patient using an electrical current. Some indications of ECT include:

  • Major depression
    • Psychotic depression
    • Treatment-resistant depression
    • Food refusal secondary to depression
    • Suicidality
  • Mania
  • Acute exacerbation of schizophrenia
  • Catatonia
  • On and off phenomenon in Parkinson's disease
  • Neuroleptic malignant disorder

Pre-treatment evaluation includes a thorough history, examination, and laboratory tests. These include full blood counts, urine tests, a chest X-ray, and ECG. The patient should not eat anything orally for 6 hours before the procedure.

The procedure is done under general anesthesia, and oxygen is administered. Methohexital is the most commonly used agent. Thiopental is another agent that can be used. A muscle relaxant such as succinylcholine is also administered to reduce the risk of injuries resulting from the seizure.

A brief muscular contraction is seen in the jaw and facial muscles with the flow of current. Adverse effects include confusion and delirium shortly after the procedure, memory impairment, and other minor injuries.

Other options: 

Option A - Narcissistic personality disorder is treated with psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Lithium is used for mood swings. Antidepressants may also be used since these patients are prone to depression.

Option B - Generalized anxiety disorder is treated with a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. The three main drugs that are used are benzodiazepines, buspirone, and venlafaxine.

Option C - ECT is not known to be effective in conversion disorder. It usually resolves spontaneously. Insight-oriented supportive therapy, anxiolytics, and psychoanalysis are treatment modalities used.

questions.text:
An alcoholic man is admitted to a rehabilitation center for alcohol deaddiction. After three days, he develops visual hallucinations. His vital signs are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Pulse rate: 124 bpm
Blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg
Temperature: 101ºF
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an alcohol-dependent patient with tactile hallucinations, tachycardia, hypertension and fever following alcohol withdrawal indicates a likely diagnosis of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs within a week of a person stopping or reducing the intake of alcohol. Acute infection, hepatitis, and pancreatitis predispose a person in withdrawal to develop delirium tremens. Clinically, patients present with confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Visual or tactile hallucinations are also seen, along with features of autonomic hyperactivity like tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, insomnia, and hypertension. 

Delirium tremend is managed with benzodiazepines such as lorazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours). It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute encephalopathy caused due to thiamine deficiency in alcohol-dependent patients who tend to have micronutrient deficiencies. Patients present with a characteristic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and global confusion. Treatment includes immediate administration of a high dose of 500 mg intravenous thiamine.

Option B: Korsakoff psychosis is an amnestic syndrome that occurs due to thiamine deficiency in alcohol-dependent patients. The clinical features include impairment of memory, confabulations, and disordered temporal sequencing. Treatment includes 100 mg of oral thiamine daily for 3-12 months.

Option D: In alcohol intoxication, there is a history of recent ingestion of alcohol. Patients present with slurred speech, incoordination, unsteady gait, and nystagmus. Impairments in attention and memory are also seen.

questions.text:
A concerned mother brings her child with the complaints that she gets up at night and walks around the room for around 15-20 minutes. During the episode, she does not respond when spoken to, even though her eyes are open and eventually goes back to bed. Identify the correct statements about this condition.

1. It occurs in the rapid eye movement (REM) phase of sleep
2. It can be secondary to other sleep disorders
3. The patient does not have full consciousness
4. The person is responsible for any criminal actions performed in this state
5. The patient may ingest food during such episodes
questions.solution:
The condition described above is known as somnambulism (sleepwalking), and the correct statements about it are 2, 3, and 5.

Somnambulism (sleepwalking) is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities while unconscious. It occurs in the non-rapid eye movement (NREM) phase of sleep(Stage N3 sleep). 

It is more commonly seen in children between the ages of 4-8 years. It usually resolves after adolescence and is rarely seen in adults. It has a familial pattern and may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk or perform semi-purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty. During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road). Legally, the person is not criminally responsible for his acts carried out during an episode.

Forms of somnambulism include:

  • Sleep-related eating: The individual may ingest food during the episode.
  • Sleep-related sexual behavior (sexsomnia): The individual may engage in sexual activities during the episode

Management includes reassurance, maintenance of safety, and avoiding sleep deprivation. Antidepressants, relaxation techniques, and hypnosis may also be used.

questions.text: A female patient presents with sudden onset palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, and a feeling like she is being choked. Physical examination and routine investigations were within normal limits. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Occurs only in the presence of a trigger

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a classic panic attack, which can occur even in the absence of an identifiable trigger.

A panic attack is a sudden surge of intense fear or discomfort that may last from minutes to hours. Recurrent panic attacks can point to a panic disorder.

Panic attacks can also be seen in other disorders such as specific phobias, social phobias, and post-traumatic stress disorder. Unexpected panic attacks occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable situational trigger. Attacks in patients with social and specific pho­bias are usually expected in response to a specific stimulus.

Some panic attacks are neither unexpected nor expected attacks and are known as situationally predisposed panic attacks. They may or may not occur on exposure to a specific trigger, or may occur immediately after exposure or after a considerable period of time.

Four or more of the following should be present to label it a panic attack:

  • Palpitations, pounding heart, or tachycardia
  • Perspiration
  • Trembling 
  • Breathlessness or a sensation of smothering
  • Feelings of choking
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, unsteadiness, light-headedness, or fainting 
  • Chills or heat sensations
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (feeling detached from oneself)
  • Fear of losing control 
  • Fear of death

Alprazolam and paroxetine can be used for the medical management of panic disorders. Cognitive and behavior therapies can also prove effective.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a sudden loss of vision in both eyes that occurred after a stressful argument with her boss. On examination, her visual acuity is recorded as 6/6 in each eye, and her pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. There are no abnormalities found on ophthalmic examination or in other neurological evaluations. When asked to follow a moving object or identify visual stimuli, she demonstrates inconsistent performance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is conversion disorder /functional neurologic symptom disorder.

Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anaesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Conversion disorder usually resolves spontaneously. Insight-oriented or behavioural therapy is also helpful. Hypnosis and anxiolytics are used in some cases. 

Other options: 

Option B: Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. Some clinical features include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), especially in its ischemic form, usually presents with severe visual loss, marked retinal haemorrhages, cotton wool spots, optic disc oedema, and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), often accompanied by detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic examination. However, this patient has normal visual acuity, normal pupillary reactions, and no detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic or neurological exams, making CRVO an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option D: Eales' disease, common in young Asian males, features recurrent vitreous haemorrhage and retinal neovascularization due to peripheral retinal vein inflammation. It presents with a reddish vitreous mass and can lead to vision loss and complications like retinal detachment. However, it is less likely here due to the patient’s demographics and absence of characteristic findings.

  • La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with schizophrenia for which he was treated with chlorpromazine and olanzapine for a month each. Despite treatment with two different antipsychotics, the symptoms still persist. Which drug is recommended to be used next in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with poor response to two antipsychotics is suggestive of resistant schizophrenia, and the drug that is recommended to be used next is clozapine.

Treatment-resistant schizophrenia refers to the failure to respond to at least two trials of antipsychotics of adequate dose and duration. A 4-6 week of antipsychotic on an adequate dose is considered an adequate trial. If patients show even a mild amount of improvement during this period, it may be reasonable to wait before changing a medication, since patients may improve at a steady rate for 3 to 6 months.

Clozapine, a second-generation antipsychotic (atypical antipsychotic) is used for patients who respond poorly to dopamine receptor antagonists (typical antipsychotic). It has mixed 5HT2A-D2 receptor antagonism. Other uses of clozapine are tardive dyskinesia, refractory mania, psychotic depression, and Huntington's disease.

Adverse effects of clozapine include sedation, agranulocytosis, weight gain, and postural hypotension. It is also associated with an increased risk of seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Chlorpromazine is a first-generation antipsychotic drug used in schizophrenia as a first-line agent.

Option B: Fluphenazine is a first-generation antipsychotic drug. It is used in schizophrenia and acute mania.

Option C: Quetiapine is a second-generation antipsychotic drug used in schizophrenia, acute mania, and bipolar depression.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with the complaint that she needs to check if the front door of her home is locked at least 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She understands that this habit is irrational but she feels extremely anxious due to repetitive thoughts that her door is unlocked but has not been treated for the condition before.  which of these management options would you suggest for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder which can be managed by behavior therapy.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

Behavior therapy and pharmacotherapy can be used alone or in combination for the management of this condition. Behavior therapy is thought to be longer-lasting than pharmacotherapy. Hence, it is considered the treatment of choice by many clinicians. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or clomipramine are used for medical management.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviors are called compulsions, such as counting and checking, and are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

It is associated with other mental disorders such as major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and specific phobias. In adults, it is seen with equal prevalence among men and women. The four major symptom patterns include contamination, pathological doubt, intrusive thoughts, and symmetry.

Other options:

Option A: Cingulotomy is carried out in severe and treatment-unresponsive patients.

Option B: Electroconvulsive therapy can be considered in treatment-resistant and chronically debilitating conditions.

Option D: Antipsychotics such as risperidone have been helpful in some cases when added to the treatment.

questions.text: A patient with a severe, treatment-resistant neuropsychiatric condition is referred to the neurosurgery OPD. The surgeon proposes a burr-hole procedure where the given sites are destroyed via thermocoagulation. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of anterior cingulotomy (ACING), which is a neurosurgical treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder. Anterior cingulotomy involves creating bilateral lesions in the anterior cingulate cortex under stereotactic guidance. 

Subcaudate tractotomy (capsulotomy) can also be used in the management of treatment-unresponsive OCD.

Prefrontal lobotomy was introduced by Egas Moniz as a method of psychosurgery for treatment-resistant mental disorders, particularly major depressive disorder and OCD.

Other indications for psychosurgery include:

  • Chronic and incapacitating schizophrenia with severe depression not responding to all modes of treatment.
  • Chronic and incapacitating anxiety disorder not responding to all modes of treatment.

questions.text: A male patient has presented with complaints of excessive sweating,  severe muscle aches, yawning, profuse diarrhea, and insomnia. He had been using methadone twice daily and stopped the use two days back. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is opioid withdrawal, due to the sudden stoppage of methadone, an opioid agonist.

Opioid withdrawal arises after cessation or reduction of heavy and prolonged opioid use. It can also be due to the administration of an opioid antagonist after a period of opioid use. Some of the clinical features are dysphoria, nausea, vomiting, muscle aches, lacrimation, yawning, and fever. Diarrhea, insomnia, pupillary dilation, and sweating can also be seen. It results in clinically significant distress and impairment of social or occupational functioning. A single injection of morphine or heroin during the abstinence period alleviates all the symptoms.

Morphine, heroin, methadone, and meperidine are the various opioid drugs. Methadone withdrawal generally begins in 1-3 days after the last dose and ends in 10-14 days.

Other options:

Option A: Cocaine use disorder is marked by irritability, inability to concentrate, insomnia, nasal congestion, and weight loss. Social and occupation functioning is usually impaired.

Option B: Opioid intoxication is characterized by bradycardia, hypotension, respiratory depression, hypothermia, and pinpoint pupils. Respiratory depression can even result in death.

Option C: Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) usage results in dilated pupils, increased deep tendon reflexes, and muscle tension. Mild motor incoordination and ataxia are also common features.

questions.text: A patient who believes that aliens are trying to abduct him and he has been hearing them for the past 6 months is bought to the psychiatric outpatient department.  He also exhibits  reduced emotional expression. Which of the following points to a poor prognosis in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with auditory hallucinations and reduced emotional expression points to a diagnosis of schizophrenia. The presence of anhedonia points to a poor prognosis in this condition.

Schizophrenia is a disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and catatonic behavior.

The symptoms are mainly divided into negative or positive symptoms. Negative symptoms are diminished emotional expression, avolition, anhedonia, alogia, and asociality. Examples of positive symptoms include hallucinations and delusions. 

There are several factors that affect the prognosis of schizophrenia:

Dopamine excess is believed to play an important role in the development of the disease. A genetic component is also implicated. It is equally seen in males and females. 

Some cases may require short stays at the hospital either for patient safety or for stabilization of medications. Anti-psychotics are the mainstay of treatment. They mainly act by antagonizing the postsynaptic dopamine receptors in the brain. Psychosocial therapy also plays an important role and can augment clinical improvement.

The different disorders of perception are:

Illusion is the incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus. It differs from hallucinations in that an actual external stimulus is present. 

Hallucination is the perception in the absence of any stimulus. It is characterized by the clarity and impact of a true perception but there is no external stimulus. The most frequently encountered hallucination in the psychiatric setting is auditory hallucinations. Other hallucinations include visual, tactile, olfactory, and gustatory hallucinations.

Depersonalization is the feeling of not being themselves or that something has changed. There is a feeling of unreality or detachment from one's whole self or from some aspects of self. This can be in terms of feelings (hypoemotionality), thoughts, or sensations. Sometimes it can be a diminished sense of agency, such as feeling robotic, or like an automaton.

Derealization refers to the feeling that one's environment has changed in some strange way that is difficult to describe. There is an experience of unreality or detachment with respect to surroundings. Individuals or objects can appear foggy, dreamlike, or visually distorted.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with patchy hair loss, characterized by short, broken strands appearing together with long, normal hairs in the affected areas as shown below.  Biopsy shows perifollicular hemorrhage. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis based on the history and findings, along with the image is trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania (trichotillosis) is considered an OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder) spectrum disorder marked by gratification from pulling one's own hair. Underlying anxieties or depression could be associated. The vertex region of the scalp is most commonly involved. 

The disease onset can be either during childhood between the ages 5-12, or during adulthood. Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages. Intrafollicular pigment casts can be also observed. The presence of numerous empty canals is the most consistent feature. Also, severely damaged follicles and clefts in the hair matrix are also seen.

Complications include scarring hair loss, folliculitis, and keloid formation. Trichobezoar, which is an aggregation of the hair in the stomach or small intestine is a rare complication. Habit reversal and other forms of cognitive behavioral therapy are the first-line treatment modalities. High doses of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors can be used if there is underlying anxiety or depression.

Other options:

Option A: The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of hair loss. Some broken hairs can be seen which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T lymphocyte infiltration. 

Option B: Tinea capitis is used to describe an infection of the scalp by the dermatophyte group of fungi. The most common pathogenic species are Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum. The presentation can vary from hair breakage associated with scaling to widespread inflammatory mass on the scalp.

Option D: Alopecia after chemotherapy is known as anagen effluvium. The hair loss is generally acute and diffuse. Hair shedding generally starts within 1–3 weeks and is completed within 1–2 months of initiation of chemotherapy.

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: A male patient is being treated for chronic schizophrenia with haloperidol. One week after the initiation of therapy, he complains of restlessness, inability to sit in one place, and fidgetiness. Which of the following is the most effective treatment for this condition?

questions.solution:
The clinical features point to a diagnosis of medication-induced acute akathisia for which the most effective treatment is the addition of a beta-blocker.

Akathisia is the subjective feelings and/or objective signs of restlessness. These include rocking motions while sitting, jitteriness, pacing, and inability to relax. Medication-induced akathisia develops within a few weeks of starting or raising the dose of certain medications. Antipsychotics, antidepressants, and sympathomimetics have been implicated in causing the condition. It can also be seen after reducing a medication used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms.

Dose-reduction, pharmacotherapy, and change of neuroleptic are the primary modalities used in the treatment. Beta-blockers like propranolol are considered the most effective agents. Benzodiazepines like lorazepam and anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are used next.

It is more commonly seen in middle-aged women. It can be associated with a poor treatment outcome.

Dissociative identity disorder is marked by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states. It was previously called multiple personality disorder. It is thought to arise due to childhood trauma, most frequently associated with physical or sexual abuse during early childhood.

The identities or personality states are called, alters, self­ states, or alter identities. Each has its own pattern of perceiving and thinking about the environment and self. Most affected patients also suffer from a mood disorder, generally one of the depression spectrum disorders. Obsessive-compulsive personality traits are also frequently associated. Psychotherapy and hypnosis are used to treat the condition. Antidepressants can be used for the stabilization of mood. In some patients with refractory mood disorders, electroconvulsive therapy can be tried.

Other options:

Option A: Dissociative fugue refers to sudden travel away from home associated with partial or complete memory loss about one's identity.

Option B: Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder and is of two types. Bipolar I disorder requires at least one episode of mania for diagnosis. Bipolar II disorder is characterized by at least one major depressive episode (for at least 2 weeks) and a hypomanic episode (for at least 4 days) each.

Option D: Depersonalization is the feeling of not being themselves or that something has changed. There is a feeling of unreality or detachment from one's whole self or from some aspects of self.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 18-year-old daughter for a psychiatric evaluation as she has no friends and is overly fascinated by magical thoughts.  She also believes she has superpowers. What is the most likely type of personality disorder she has?
questions.solution:
The most likely personality disorder based on the clinical features is schizotypal personality disorder.

Inability to maintain close relationships, magical thinking, and a belief that they possess superpowers are suggestive of schizotypal personality disorder.

A schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. It is characterized by strange perceptions, disturbed thinking, and behavior. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition. Pscytherapy is the first line treatment for pateints for schizotypal personality disorder.

Personality disorders are divided into three clusters:

  • Cluster A: Schizotypal, schizoid, and paranoid
  • Cluster B: Narcissistic, borderline, antisocial, and histrionic
  • Cluster C: Obsessive-compulsive, dependent, and avoidant

Other options:

Option A: Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection and leads a socially withdrawn life but a strong desire for relationships.

Option B: Narcissistic personality disorder is marked by a heightened sense of self-importance. Individuals with this personality disorder display a lack of empathy and grandiose feelings. This is to mask their fragile self-esteem and vulnerability.

Option C- Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a tendency for social withdrawal, isolation, and introversion. They tend to take up jobs that require minimal interpersonal interaction. They are emotionally detached, aloof, and avoid eye contact.

questions.text: A  girl from an affluent family had a history of repeated arrests for shoplifting. During her most recent arrest, she was found with a bag full of toothbrushes and was unable to explain the reason she stole them. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: The stolen items are of no monetary value
No feeling of gratification or relief after the theft
Stealing is not in response to rage, vengeance or delusion

questions.solution:
The above clinical stem is suggestive of kleptomania. The person feels a sense of pleasure and gratification after performing the act.

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects which are of no value to the person. The individual can usually afford the object or does not need it but it is the act of stealing itself that is the goal. The stolen objects are usually given away, returned, or kept hidden. The act is not planned and carried out alone.

A mounting tension is seen before carrying out the act. A sense of gratification follows after the act is done. It is not carried out due to rage, vengeance, delusion, or hallucination. The disorder usually manifests by late adolescence and is more commonly seen in women. The patient may also have other co-morbidities like mood, anxiety, and substance use disorders. Pathological gambling, compulsive shopping, and eating disorders are also associated. Social and occupational functioning usually remains intact.

Insight-oriented psychotherapy and psychoanalysis can be used for the management of the condition. Behavior therapy such as systematic desensitization is also effective. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as fluoxetine are used in some patients.

questions.text: An elderly man was caught peeping into a bathroom window and watching a girl disrobe. During the psychiatric evaluation, he confessed that he attains sexual gratification when he watches people naked or while they are engaged in any sexual activity without their knowledge. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Attaining sexual gratification after observing someone naked or engaged in sexual activity is called voyeurism. 

Voyeurism is also called scopophilia. It is more common in men. The voyeuristic act may be accompanied by masturbation. 

Paraphilias (perversions) are sexual stimuli or acts that are considered deviations from normal sexual behaviors. These are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm. Individuals with paraphilias do not experience sexual pleasure through stimuli that are considered normal.

Other options:

Option A: In transvestism there is a sexual urge to dress in opposite gender clothing as a means of arousal. It is diagnosed when these fantasies have been acted upon for at least six months. 

Option B: Coprophilia is attaining sexual pleasure by defecating on the partner or by being defecated on. An urge to eat feces (coprophagia) may also be seen. 

Option D: Frotteurism is characterized by the rubbing of genitals against the buttocks or any other parts of the body of a woman who is fully clothed. This is done to achieve an orgasm and usually occurs in crowded places.

Note: Exhibitionism is characterized by a recurrent urge to expose the genitals to strangers. The anticipation of the exposure results in sexual excitement and orgasm.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man has an extreme and irrational fear of heights and prefers to live on the ground floor. The thought of attending an event on the terrace of a hotel brings about intense anxiety. What are the defense mechanisms involved in this condition?
  1. Displacement
  2. Dissociation
  3. Avoidance
  4. Symbolization
  5. Reaction formation
questions.solution:
Defense mechanisms involved in this scenario are displacement, avoidance, and symbolization - 1,3,4 (Option A).

The clinical scenario of extreme fear of heights points toward acrophobia and the defense mechanisms involved in phobias are displacement, symbolization, and avoidance.

A phobia can be described as a fear that is irrational and out of proportion to the stimulus. Defense mechanisms mediate an individual's reaction to emotional conflicts and stressors. In displacement, the conflict or emotions are displaced from the actual cause to a less threatening, irrel­evant object or situation. 

The primary source of the conflict may have a direct associative connec­tion with the phobic object or situation that symbolizes it. This object is something the person can avoid and this protects the person from the anxiety attached to the original object or idea, which is the defense mechanism of symbolization.

The phobic situation or the object is usually something that the person can avoid. With the defense mechanism of avoidance, the person can escape the anxiety associated with it. 

Behavioral therapy is the most effective treatment for phobias. Insight-oriented therapy, virtual therapy, and exposure therapy are also used for the treatment of phobic disorders and specific phobias. β-receptor blockers can be used for the treatment of specific phobias, particularly if it is associated with panic attacks. Benzodiazepines can also be used but the chronic nature of the disease limits its effect. Paroxetine and sertraline can be used to manage social anxiety. 

Dissociation is the splitting of mental contents in clusters from conscious awareness. This allows the individual to support two contradictory truths while not being aware of them. An extreme manifestation of this mechanism is seen in dissociative identity disorder. 

Reaction formation is an unconscious defense mechanism in which the person develops a wish or impulse that is a direct antithesis to the ones that are harbored consciously or unconsciously. It develops against impulses that are unacceptable to the ego.

  • Phobia - displacement

  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with a 25-day history of hearing voices that ask him to jump from the 10th floor of his building. He has a labile mood. On further probing, he reveals that he had lost his mother a month back in an accident that happened before his eyes. Which of the following statements is true for his condition?
  1. The diagnosis is schizophrenia
  2. His condition is likely to be brief psychotic disorder
  3. Complete remission usually occurs
  4. Negative symptoms are part of the diagnostic criteria
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with auditory hallucinations in a patient with a history of witnessing a traumatic event is highly suggestive of the diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder.

For a diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, the symptoms should have lasted for at least a day but less than a month. It should not be associated with a mood disorder, substance abuse disorder, or psychotic disorder due to an underlying medical condition. It may also occur following a traumatic life event. It is commonly seen in women, young people, and those with existing personality disorders. The criteria for diagnosis is the same as that for schizophrenia but without negative symptoms.

Clinical features include delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized speech. At least one of these symptoms of psychosis is required for diagnosis. Other signs like disorganized or catatonic behavior, emotional volatility, bizarre behavior, and screaming may also be seen.

Brief psychotic disorder is classified into the following subtypes:

  • After a stressor
  • Without a stressor
  • Postpartum onset

The diagnosis is usually retrospective, as the diagnosis requires complete remission of symptoms, which usually occurs in a month. There is an eventual complete return to the premorbid level of functioning.

Management includes hospitalization and psychotherapy. The involvement of the family is also recommended. Antipsychotics and benzodiazepines are also used.

Schizophrenia is a disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and catatonic behavior. At least two of the first three symptoms should be present for a duration of one month. Continuous signs of disturbance should be seen for at least 6 months.

questions.text: The parents of a 6-year-old child were informed that he does not speak at all in school but performs well academically. His parents are surprised as he communicates normally at home with no abnormal behavior. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario described is selective mutism. 

Selective mutism refers to the persistent lack of speaking in one or more specific social situations. The child is able to speak well in other situations, like at home. 

The disorder may develop in children between 4 to 8 years of age and is associated with a social anxiety disorder. They may have symptoms of separation anxi­ety disorder, school refusal, and delayed language acquisition. The child may be either completely silent at school or maybe just whispering. Rarely, a child may be silent at home but communicate normally at school.

Maternal overprotection and anxiety disorders in parents may exacerbate the condition. Some children may develop selective mutism after emotional or physical trauma.

Selectively mute children may have an increased risk for delayed speech and language acquisition and disturbances in auditory processing. They may also exhibit behavioral disturbances, like temper tan­trums and oppositional behavior at home.

Treatment includes a combination of psychoeducation for the family, cognitive behavioral therapy, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors if needed. Pre-school children seem to have a positive response to a therapeutic nursery.

Other options:

Option A: Expressive language deficits refer to a shortfall in expressive language development with normal nonverbal intellectual function. It is frequently seen in autism spectrum disorders. It is marked by limited vocabulary and variable articulation.

Option B: In severe intellectual disability children can present with minimal speech during preschool years along with impaired motor development. Some language development might occur later on.

Option D: Rett syndrome is a progressive autism spectrum disorder predominantly seen in girls. The onset is after a few months of apparently normal development. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills are seen.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand-wringing movements and finger-licking. Detailed history revealed regression of language milestones. Microcephaly was noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rett syndrome based on the stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behavior with regressed language milestones, and microcephaly.

Rett syndrome is a progressive condition predominantly seen in girls. Under the international classification of diseases, the tenth revision falls under pervasive development disorder. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, 5th edition (DSM-5) considers it an autism spectrum disorder, though there are marked differences between them.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Other clinical features include stereotypic hand movements such as wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills can also be seen. Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but growth begins to decelerate between the ages of 6 months to 1 year. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Other options:

Options A&D: Heller's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. It is also known as childhood disintegrative disorder. It is predominantly seen in boys. They have marked regression in intellectual, social, and language functions after 2 years of apparently normal development. 

Option B: Asperger's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. There are marked nonverbal communicative gestures and failure to develop relationships with peers. No significant delay in language milestones or cognitive development is seen. The intelligence remains normal.

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

Related Pearl: Specific phobia

Present in 10% of the population.

Clinical features:

  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for > 6 months
  • Usually develops in childhood, can develop after a traumatic event
  • Avoidance behavior

Treatment:

  • Behavioral therapy (exposure-based, systematic desensitization) is the treatment of choice
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines may help acutely
