questions.text: A 20-year-old man was brought by his father to your clinic with the complaints that he has become very irritable, excessively talkative, and spends around 12 hours playing video games for the past 8 days. However, he attends his online classes regularly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms occurring for 8 days, without causing occupational impairment (still attends his online classes regularly) point toward a diagnosis of hypomania. 

Diagnostic criteria for hypomania:

  • A distinct period of persistently elevated/irritable mood, increased energy levels, and activity lasting for at least 4 consecutive days.
  • During this period, ≥3 of the following symptoms should be present to a significant degree:
    • Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
    • Decreased requirement for sleep
    • Excessive talkativeness
    • Flight of ideas
    • Distractibility
    • Increase in goal-oriented activity or psychomotor agitation
    • Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for adverse outcomes such 
  • The episode is associated with a change in functioning that is atypical of the individual when asymptomatic and is observed by others.
  • The episode is not severe enough to cause marked deterioration in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. No psychotic episodes are seen.
  • The episode is not attributable to the use of a substance or to another medical condition.

Other options:

Option A: In mania, the symptoms should be present for at least 1 week and symptoms should be severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning. Psychotic features may also be seen in mania.

Option B: Dysthymia is also called a persistent depressive disorder. It is defined as a subaffective or subclinical depressive disorder that is insidious in onset and intermittent or persistent in the course. It lasts for at least 2 years. 

Option C: Cyclothymic disorder is a mild form of bipolar type II disorder. It is characterized by hypomania and mild depression.

questions.text: During history-taking, a patient was responding to the questions with unnecessary and irrelevant responses. He gave excessive details before he finally answered the question.  Which of the following best describes the patient's thought disorder?
questions.solution:
The thought disorder known as circumstantiality best describes this patient's thought disorder.

Circumstantiality refers to a formal thought disorder in which a patient gives irrelevant and unnecessary details. This is before finally getting to the point or the correct answer. It may be seen in schizophrenia, obsessional distur­bances, and certain cases of dementia. An example is given below.

Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper, and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

A formal thought disorder is a disturbance in the formulation of thoughts and their expression. It is characterized by loosened associations, illogical constructs, and neologisms. Derailment, neologism, perseveration, and thought blocking are some examples.

Other options:

Option A: Clang association is a formal thought disorder where the thoughts are associated with the sound of words through rhyming, rather than the meaning of the words. It is usually seen in schizophrenia or mania. An example is "I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

Option B: Flight of ideas refers to a rapid succession of multiple associations, where the thoughts appear to abruptly shift from one idea to another. It is usually seen in mania. An example is "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

Option D: Tagentiality is a formal thought disorder where the patient says something that is related to the general topic. Although, the actual answer is not given. An example is as below.

Doctor: "How has your appetite been lately?"
Patient: "I usually have dinner with my wife, but now I eat alone"

questions.text: A male patient complains of fatigue, low self-esteem, feeling hopeless, and not being able to concentrate on work. A diagnosis of dysthymia is made. What is the minimum duration of the symptoms to arrive at this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The minimum duration that the symptoms should persist in order to make a diagnosis of dysthymia /persistent depressive disorder is two years. 

Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than two years in adults (1 year in children and adolescents). It is not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression and has an insidious onset. The low mood persists for most of the day. It is accompanied by low self-esteem, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, poor appetite,  poor concentration, and hopelessness.

The onset can be either early (before the age of 21) which is more common or late. It affects both genders equally. It is frequently associated with depression, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder.

The two important differential diagnoses are minor depressive disorder and recurrent brief depressive disorder. In the former, patients have episodic symptoms and euthymic moods in between. In the latter, the episodic nature of more severe symptoms is seen.

The most effective treatment involves a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Insight-oriented psychotherapy, cognitive therapy, and behavioral therapy are used. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like escitalopram and sertraline are effective.

Hospitalization is usually not indicated in dysthymia. However, severe symptoms, marked impairment in social or occupational functioning, and suicidal ideation require hospitalization.

questions.text: In children and adolescents treated with an SSRI, there appears to be an increased risk of particular ideations. Clinicians are therefore advised to remain vigilant of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) should be used carefully in the young for the management of depression due to increased suicidal ideation. In children and adolescents, there appears to be a slightly increased risk of suicidal ideations and attempts, but not of completed suicide.

Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is started on SSRIs and hence patients have the energy to act on their thoughts of deliberate self-harm and suicide (paradoxical suicide).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic feature of Tourette’s disorder?

choices.text: Attributable to physiological effects of a substance use
Waxing and waning tics that are present for at least a year after onset
Presence of motor tics and at least one vocal tic

questions.solution:
Attributable to physiological effects of a substance is not a diagnostic criterion for Tourette's disorder.

One of the diagnostic features of Tourette’s disorder is that the disturbance is not a direct physiological effect of any stimulant or substance use. 

Tourette's disorder is the most severe tic disorder that more commonly affects boys. It is also associated with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

According to the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5), the following criteria are used for diagnosis:

  • Multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic should be present during the illness. It need not be concurrent.
  • The onset of illness is before the age of 18
  • The tics can wax and wane in frequency but should persist for at least a year since the first tic onset
  • The disturbance should not be attributable to the use of substances such as cocaine or medical conditions such as Huntington's disease.

The condition is thought to be a genetic disorder. Initially, the tics involve the face and neck which then progresses downwards. It usually disappears during sleep and is attenuated by relaxation or absorption in an activity. 

Mild cases may not require treatment. In severe cases, behavioral interventions are the first line of treatment. Psychoeducation is recommended for families to understand the natural history of the disease. Antipsychotic agents such as risperidone are used for the treatment of tics. Noradrenergic drugs like clonidine can be used for children with comorbid ADHD.
